Hilbert spaces

Let H\mathcal{H}H be a separable infinite-dimensional Hilbert space and assume that {en}\set{e_n}{en​} is an orthonormal system in H\mathcal{H}H. Let {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ be another orthonormal system which is complete, i.e., the closure of the span of the {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ is all of H\mathcal{H}H.

  1. Show that if ∑n=1∞∥fn−en∥2<1\sum_{n=1}^\infty \norm{f_n - e_n}^2 < 1∑n=1∞​∥fn​−en​∥2<1, then the orthonormal system {en}n\set{e_n}_n{en​}n​ is also complete.
  2. Assume that we only have ∑n=1∞∥fn−en∥2<∞\sum_{n=1}^\infty \norm{f_n - e_n}^2 < \infty∑n=1∞​∥fn​−en​∥2<∞. Prove that it is still true that {en}n\set{e_n}_n{en​}n​ is complete.
Solution.

  1. Let x∈Hx \in \mathcal{H}x∈H be such that ⟨x,en⟩=0\inner{x, e_n} = 0⟨x,en​⟩=0 for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1. Since {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ is complete, we can write x=∑n=1∞⟨x,fn⟩fnx = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \inner{x, f_n}f_nx=∑n=1∞​⟨x,fn​⟩fn​. To make use of the condition given, set y=∑n=1∞⟨x,fn⟩eny = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \inner{x, f_n}e_ny=∑n=1∞​⟨x,fn​⟩en​, which gives

    ∥x−y∥2=∥∑n=1∞⟨x,en⟩(en−fn)∥2≤(∑n=1∞∣⟨x,fn⟩∣∥en−fn∥)2≤(∑n=1∞∣⟨x,fn⟩∣2)(∑n=1∞∥en−fn∥2)(Cauchy-Schwarz)≤∥x∥2.\begin{aligned} \norm{x - y}^2 &= \norm{\sum_{n=1}^\infty \inner{x, e_n}\p{e_n - f_n}}^2 \\ &\leq \p{\sum_{n=1}^\infty \abs{\inner{x, f_n}}\norm{e_n - f_n}}^2 \\ &\leq \p{\sum_{n=1}^\infty \abs{\inner{x, f_n}}^2} \p{\sum_{n=1}^\infty \norm{e_n - f_n}^2} && \p{\text{Cauchy-Schwarz}} \\ &\leq \norm{x}^2. \end{aligned}∥x−y∥2​=∥∥​n=1∑∞​⟨x,en​⟩(en​−fn​)∥∥​2≤(n=1∑∞​∣⟨x,fn​⟩∣∥en​−fn​∥)2≤(n=1∑∞​∣⟨x,fn​⟩∣2)(n=1∑∞​∥en​−fn​∥2)≤∥x∥2.​​(Cauchy-Schwarz)​

    But by assumption, ⟨x,en⟩=0\inner{x, e_n} = 0⟨x,en​⟩=0 for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, which implies that ⟨x,y⟩=0\inner{x, y} = 0⟨x,y⟩=0. Hence, by the Pythagorean theorem,

    ∥x∥2+∥y∥2≤∥x∥2  ⟹  y=0,\norm{x}^2 + \norm{y}^2 \leq \norm{x}^2 \implies y = 0,∥x∥2+∥y∥2≤∥x∥2⟹y=0,

    and so ⟨x,fn⟩=0\inner{x, f_n} = 0⟨x,fn​⟩=0 for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1 as well. Since {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ was complete, this implies that x=0x = 0x=0, so {xn}n\set{x_n}_n{xn​}n​ is complete as well.

  2. For N∈NN \in \NN∈N, let EN=span⁡{eN,eN+1,…}‾E_N = \cl{\span{\set{e_N, e_{N+1}, \ldots}}}EN​=span{eN​,eN+1​,…}​ and FN=span⁡{fN,fN+1,…}‾F_N = \cl{\span{\set{f_N, f_{N+1}, \ldots}}}FN​=span{fN​,fN+1​,…}​. Since these are closed subspaces, we have orthogonal projections πEN\pi_{E_N}πEN​​ and πVN\pi_{V_N}πVN​​, respectively. Then for any x∈Hx \in \mathcal{H}x∈H,

    ∥πEN(x)−πVN(x)∥=∥∑n=N∞⟨x,en⟩en−∑n=N∞⟨x,fn⟩fn∥≤∥∑n=N∞⟨x,en⟩(en−fn)∥+∥∑n=N∞⟨x,en−fn⟩fn∥≤∑n=N∞∣⟨x,en⟩∣∥en−fn∥+(∑n=N∞∣⟨x,en−fn⟩∣2)1/2≤(∑n=N∞∣⟨x,en⟩∣2)1/2(∑n=N∞∥en−fn∥2)1/2+(∑n=N∞∥x∥2∥en−fn∥2)1/2(Cauchy-Schwarz)≤2∥x∥(∑n=N∞∥en−fn∥2)1/2.(Bessel’s inequality)\begin{aligned} \norm{\pi_{E_N}\p{x} - \pi_{V_N}\p{x}} &= \norm{\sum_{n=N}^\infty \inner{x, e_n}e_n - \sum_{n=N}^\infty \inner{x, f_n}f_n} \\ &\leq \norm{\sum_{n=N}^\infty \inner{x, e_n}\p{e_n - f_n}} + \norm{\sum_{n=N}^\infty \inner{x, e_n - f_n}f_n} \\ &\leq \sum_{n=N}^\infty \abs{\inner{x, e_n}} \norm{e_n - f_n} + \p{\sum_{n=N}^\infty \abs{\inner{x, e_n - f_n}}^2}^{1/2} \\ &\leq \p{\sum_{n=N}^\infty \abs{\inner{x, e_n}}^2}^{1/2} \p{\sum_{n=N}^\infty \norm{e_n - f_n}^2}^{1/2} + \p{\sum_{n=N}^\infty \norm{x}^2 \norm{e_n - f_n}^2}^{1/2} && \p{\text{Cauchy-Schwarz}} \\ &\leq 2\norm{x} \p{\sum_{n=N}^\infty \norm{e_n - f_n}^2}^{1/2}. && \p{\text{Bessel's inequality}} \end{aligned}∥πEN​​(x)−πVN​​(x)∥​=∥∥​n=N∑∞​⟨x,en​⟩en​−n=N∑∞​⟨x,fn​⟩fn​∥∥​≤∥∥​n=N∑∞​⟨x,en​⟩(en​−fn​)∥∥​+∥∥​n=N∑∞​⟨x,en​−fn​⟩fn​∥∥​≤n=N∑∞​∣⟨x,en​⟩∣∥en​−fn​∥+(n=N∑∞​∣⟨x,en​−fn​⟩∣2)1/2≤(n=N∑∞​∣⟨x,en​⟩∣2)1/2(n=N∑∞​∥en​−fn​∥2)1/2+(n=N∑∞​∥x∥2∥en​−fn​∥2)1/2≤2∥x∥(n=N∑∞​∥en​−fn​∥2)1/2.​​(Cauchy-Schwarz)(Bessel’s inequality)​

    We will show that for large values of NNN, ENE_NEN​ and FNF_NFN​ intuitively capture the same amount of information. More precisely, we will show that because FN⊥F_N^\perpFN⊥​ is finite dimensional ({fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ is a complete orthonormal system), this forces EN⊥E_N^\perpEN⊥​ to be finite dimensional as well.

    Hence, ∥πEN−πFN∥→0\norm{\pi_{E_N} - \pi_{F_N}} \to 0∥πEN​​−πFN​​∥→0 as N→∞N \to \inftyN→∞. Notice also that H=EN⊕EN⊥=FN⊕FN⊥\mathcal{H} = E_N \oplus E_N^\perp = F_N \oplus F_N^\perpH=EN​⊕EN⊥​=FN​⊕FN⊥​, which means πEN⊥=id⁡−πEN\pi_{E_N^\perp} = \id - \pi_{E_N}πEN⊥​​=id−πEN​​ and πFN⊥=id⁡−πFN\pi_{F_N^\perp} = \id - \pi_{F_N}πFN⊥​​=id−πFN​​. Thus,

    ∥πEN⊥−πFN⊥∥=∥(id⁡−πEN)−(id⁡−πFN)∥=∥πEN−πFN∥.\norm{\pi_{E_N^\perp} - \pi_{F_N^\perp}} = \norm{\p{\id - \pi_{E_N}} - \p{\id - \pi_{F_N}}} = \norm{\pi_{E_N} - \pi_{F_N}}.∥∥​πEN⊥​​−πFN⊥​​∥∥​=∥(id−πEN​​)−(id−πFN​​)∥=∥πEN​​−πFN​​∥.

    Let NNN be large enough so that ∥πEN⊥−πFN⊥∥<12\norm{\pi_{E_N^\perp} - \pi_{F_N^\perp}} < \frac{1}{2}∥∥​πEN⊥​​−πFN⊥​​∥∥​<21​. Since FN⊥F_N^\perpFN⊥​ has dimension N−1N - 1N−1, any set {x1,…,xn}\set{x_1, \ldots, x_n}{x1​,…,xn​} of NNN elements must be linearly dependent after projecting to FN⊥F_N^\perpFN⊥​. In particular, if x1,…,xn∈EN⊥x_1, \ldots, x_n \in E_N^\perpx1​,…,xn​∈EN⊥​, then there exist c1,…,cnc_1, \ldots, c_nc1​,…,cn​ such that

    0=∑n=1NcnπFN(xn)=πFN(∑n=1Ncnxn).0 = \sum_{n=1}^N c_n\pi_{F_N}\p{x_n} = \pi_{F_N}\p{\sum_{n=1}^N c_nx_n}.0=n=1∑N​cn​πFN​​(xn​)=πFN​​(n=1∑N​cn​xn​).

    Then by the triangle inequality,

    ∥∑n=1Ncnxn∥=∥πEN(∑n=1Ncnxn)∥≤∥(πEN−πFN)(∑n=1Ncnxn)∥+∥πFN(∑n=1Ncnxn)∥≤∥πEN−πFN∥∥∑n=1Ncnxn∥≤12∥∑n=1Ncnxn∥,\begin{aligned} \norm{\sum_{n=1}^N c_nx_n} &= \norm{\pi_{E_N}\p{\sum_{n=1}^N c_nx_n}} \\ &\leq \norm{\p{\pi_{E_N} - \pi_{F_N}}\p{\sum_{n=1}^N c_nx_n}} + \norm{\pi_{F_N}\p{\sum_{n=1}^N c_nx_n}} \\ &\leq \norm{\pi_{E_N} - \pi_{F_N}} \norm{\sum_{n=1}^N c_nx_n} \\ &\leq \frac{1}{2}\norm{\sum_{n=1}^N c_nx_n}, \end{aligned}∥∥​n=1∑N​cn​xn​∥∥​​=∥∥​πEN​​(n=1∑N​cn​xn​)∥∥​≤∥∥​(πEN​​−πFN​​)(n=1∑N​cn​xn​)∥∥​+∥∥​πFN​​(n=1∑N​cn​xn​)∥∥​≤∥πEN​​−πFN​​∥∥∥​n=1∑N​cn​xn​∥∥​≤21​∥∥​n=1∑N​cn​xn​∥∥​,​

    which implies that ∑n=1Ncnxn=0\sum_{n=1}^N c_nx_n = 0∑n=1N​cn​xn​=0, i.e., {x1,…,xn}\set{x_1, \ldots, x_n}{x1​,…,xn​} is linearly dependent in EN⊥E_N^\perpEN⊥​. Since these vectors were arbitrary, it follows that dim⁡EN⊥≤N−1\dim{E_N^\perp} \leq N - 1dimEN⊥​≤N−1. But EN⊥E_N^\perpEN⊥​ contain the orthonormal set {e1,…,eN−1}\set{e_1, \ldots, e_{N-1}}{e1​,…,eN−1​}, so dim⁡EN⊥=N−1\dim{E_N^\perp} = N - 1dimEN⊥​=N−1, i.e., {e1,…,eN−1}\set{e_1, \ldots, e_{N-1}}{e1​,…,eN−1​} spans EN⊥E_N^\perpEN⊥​, and so {en}n\set{e_n}_n{en​}n​ is a complete orthonormal system.
